Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Atmospheric Dust as an Archive and Agent of Climate Change During the Late Paleozoic Icehouse
Award.AbstractNarration:
COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Atmospheric Dust as an Archive and Agent of Climate Change During the Late Paleozoic Icehouse

Gerilyn Soreghan, Michael Soreghan, University of Oklahoma Ear-0746042
Vadimir Davydov, Boise State University, EAR-0746107
Natalie Mahowald, Cornell University, EAR-0745961
Timothy W. Lyons, Univ. California, Riverside, EAR-0745602

Abstract
Atmospheric dust archives and drives climate change. Dust preserved in marine and continental sediments and ice has shed light on recent climate change, and dust also impacts climate via direct and indirect effects on the amount of solar energy received at Earth's surface, and by fertilization that stimulates primary productivity and thus the carbon cycle. However, the character and magnitude of the aerosol effect remains a poorly constrained variable in climate models, thus limiting the predictive capability of these models.
In this research, PIs propose to assess the 'dust effect' by investigating the geologic record of a particularly dusty interval on Earth. The late Paleozoic world, 300 million years ago, was remarkably dusty, with dust flux varying on both million-year and millennial scales. This time period is also attractive as the last time that Earth's climate was analogous to today's, with large polar ice sheets. Here, PIs propose to test the overarching hypothesis that the abundant dust played a significant role in driving changes in late Paleozoic climate and linked (e.g. biotic) systems, through direct, indirect, and feedback effects. They will investigate how dust flux, atmospheric circulation, and dust transport varied between glacials and interglacials, how dust forced changes in tropical climate, and how the biosphere responded to such high atmospheric dustiness. To address these questions, PIs are targeting two time slices in localities spanning the girth of the tropics. They will examine dust distribution, assess atmospheric dustiness and wind strength and direction, and use geochemistry to examine effects on marine life. They will correlate among localities using fossils and radioisotopic dating. PIs will use the data they collect as input for climate- and dust-modeling experiments, to assess the direct and indirect effects of dust on atmospheric behavior and undertake biogeochemical modeling aimed at assessing the impact of variable nutrient fluxes on cycling of carbon.
Intellectual Merit-- Results of this research will provide a high-resolution reconstruction of climate for the tropics and reveal the effects of dust on climate and life in a world characterized by variable dust flux on various timescales, within a 'glacial' world like today's. Owing to the known importance but remaining uncertainty of the roles of dust and associated aerosols in the climate system, our data will have predictive utility in expanding our understanding of Earth-system behavior across geologic time, and will provide important constraints useful for improving climate modeling.
Broader Impacts--This project will involve heavy student participation (graduate and undergraduate levels), cross-disciplinary training among geologists, geochemists, and climate modelers, both in the field and laboratory. Undergraduates (geology and education majors) and minority middle-schoolers will take part through mentoring programs. Data will be archived and shared using newly developed web-accessible tools. Finally, we will use results of this research to guide the development of a traveling exhibit on the 'Paleozoic Dust Bowl' in conjunction with the Oklahoma Museum of Natural History and incorporate results in an outreach course taught (by co-PIs) at the Museum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Atmospheric dusts, or “aerosols” both archive and drive Earth’s climate.  That is, atmospheric dust is a well-known forcing agent of the climate system, and sedimentary accumulations of (mineral) dust provide an excellent record of climate. Although the importance of atmospheric silt and dust is well known, their effects remain poorly understood, and records of dust are known and have been studied almost exclusively from Earth’s very recent climate record (i.e., the last several millenia up to 1-2 million years of the geologic record), which greatly limits our understanding. The significance of studying dust is to improve our currently very poor understanding of the role of dust in controlling Earth’s climate system, in order to better forecast potential effects of dust (in climate models), and also to understand how dust can affect cycling of carbon through the Earth system (including the atmosphere).   Dust is known to have both a direct radiative effect in the atmosphere (e.g. it can serve to either warm or cool the atmosphere), and an indirect effect because it delivers nutrients that fertilize and stimulate primary productivity, thus sequestering atmospheric CO2 and cooling the climate. This latter effect is being investigated as a possible means to control future CO2 emissions (i.e., in geoengineering schemes).

 

The goals of this research were to investigate glacial-interglacial variations in dust fluxes and and sources in the tropical latitudes of the Earth in the “deep-time” past of 300 million years ago, during a time when the supercontinent Pangaea prevailed. This research provided high-resolution (glacial-interglacial scale and finer) reconstructions of climate (dust flux, wind directions, and effective moisture estimates) for this time period. These data were integrated with geochemical data and climate modeling to assess the range in magnitude of the effects of dust on climate in a world characterized by variable dust flux on various timescales. We chose the Earth of 300 My ago especially to highlight the effects of dust, because ongoing research suggests this was an especially dusty time in Earth history.

 

As part of this research, we studied records of dust preserved in continental regions of the (modern) western U.S., and also conducted the first examination of a truly oceanic record of deep-time dust (modern Japan). We were able to document for the first time glacial-interglacial scale changes in atmospheric dust “loading” during the Late Paleozoic (300 million years ago), showing large-scale changes in the dustiness of the atmosphere between times of glacials and interglacials, that change paleolatitudinally. Additionally, we discovered remarkably high values of iron enrichment in these paleo-dusts, which is significant owing to the possible “super-fertilization” potential of such dusts. We have also documented surprisingly coarse grains in selected dust deposits, which are a marker for especially strong storm events during these times. Large grains have rarely been documented in recent dust deposits, and their origins remain poorly understood. Additionally, we also documented evidence for a previously unknown Paleo-Tethyan monsoon. Finally, this research opened new windows on the interpretation and origin of vast deposits of paleo-loess and dust in Midcontinent North America -- a veritable "Paleozoic Dust Bowl" -- raising questions about our fundamental understanding of Earth's climate system during this interval, which is Earth's most recent example of the transition from a so-called "icehouse" to "greenhouse" conditions-- a transition potentially analogous to our climatic future.
